Conversation between Michael Wong and Ekin ChengArgument between Parkman Wong and his SuperiorScenes from Tong's childhood (i.e his first killing as a Triad)User reviews8ReviewReviewFeatured review Nothing to do with the John Woo classic. But good film none the less.Let me get one thing straight before I start reviewing Return to a Better Tomorrow. It is in no way a sequel, or prequel to John Woo's class "A Better Tomorrow" starring Chow Yun Fat.Return To A Better Tomorrow is like many underrated Hong Kong action movies. It has great action sequences, good unknown actors and a healthy storyline. The great thing about Hong Kong movies is that no matter how small the budget, it always seems to pull off pretty well. Like Robert Rodriguez's "El Mariachi" for example, even if it's not a Hong Kong action movie, considering it's budget ($7000) it's a great movie.Anyway back to Return to a Better Tomorrow. Although it has nothing to do with A Better Tomorrow, this movie does seem to take a leaf out of John Woo's classic film. Some of the scenes in RTABT do have a slight "deja-vu" feel to them, I thing the director was heavily influenced by A Better Tomorrow and decided to base a lot of the action within RTABT from Woo's ABT.The storyline has all the classic elements of a gangster/Hong Kong action movie: faith, brotherhood, trust, treachery etc, just like A Better Tomorrow, this is when RTABT does start to feel like it's been heavily influenced by the classic John Woo movie, none the less...it's still a great film, if underrated.This should please most action junkies out there, but please...don't consider it a sequel to A Better Tomorrow.7/10.helpful•32crossworlds@hotmail.comDec 9, 2002Top picksSign in to rate and Watchlist for personalized recommendationsSign inDetailsEditRelease dateJuly 14, 1994 (Hong Kong)Country of originHong KongLanguagesCantoneseEnglishAlso known as新英雄本色Filming locationsChinaProduction companiesGH PicturesGolden Harvest Pictures (China)Good Standard InternationalSee more company credits at IMDbProTechnical specsEditRuntime1 hour 43 minutesColorColorSound mixMonoAspect ratio2.35 : 1Related newsContribute to this pageSuggest an edit or add missing contentTop GapBy what name was Return to a Better Tomorrow (1994) officially released in Canada in English?AnswerSee more gapsLearn more about contributingEdit pageMore to explorePhotosTop Stars to Watch in 2024See the galleryPhotosThe Greatest Character Actors of All TimeSee the galleryListJames' 5 Picks for JanuarySee the full listRecently viewedYou have no recently viewed pagesGet the IMDb AppSign in for more accessSign in for more accessGet the IMDb AppHelpSite IndexIMDbProBox Office MojoIMDb DeveloperPress RoomAdvertisingJobsConditions of UsePrivacy PolicyYour Ads Privacy ChoicesIMDb, an Amazon company© 1990-2024 by IMDb.com, Inc.Back to top

Review by ALISTAIR LEACH ★★★★ 4 OK, let's get the obvious out of the way first, I really liked Wong Jing's "rice" here.I would however suggest this have been called "3 Triads and a little lady" instead.Ok, it takes big balls to try and make a sequel or cash in using the name of one of the most iconic Hong Kong movies of all time. However, this is Wong Jing, and I really liked it, yes he possibly could have called this something else and a) it wouldn't get as much hate and b) people may have watched it as this is possibly one of the better films of his I have seen. There is no comedy in this (a couple of throw away…
Review by HKFanatic ★★★ 2 TFW you ignore all your best instincts and decide to end the movie year of 2022 with a Wong Jing flick. This will surprise no one, I'm sure, but Jing's belated attempt to cash-in on the heroic bloodshed genre with "Return to a Better Tomorrow" is nowhere close to the quality of John Woo's iconic films. Inexplicably, the print that's streaming on HI-YAH! for this looks really, really good—sad that I'm sitting here wishing that contemporary Hollywood films looked as good as a Wong Jing movie from 1995, but that's the magic of shooting on celluloid—which is appreciated since you're going to want to see 28 year-old Ekin Cheng's hair in all its glory. Despite the title's allusions to John…
Review by Filipe Furtado ★★★ 1 As the shameless title suggests, this is Wong Jing trying to get a last buck out of the then dying heroic bloodshed cycle. It is designed to get people's memories of Woo with none of the craft or conviction. Return to a Better Tomorrow is quick, brash, very violent at spots, better in the shootouts than the brotherhood melodrama. The action is more impressive for what happens that how well designed and shot it is. Gutter cinema.
Review by Sam ★★★½ Wong Jing’s homage/loose remake of A BETTER TOMORROW is kinetic, only-in-Hong Kong, bullet-flying, heroic bloodshed ecstasy with added saxophone overkill, as well as a stacked cast of HK vets (including Lau Ching-Wan, Chingmy Yau, Michael Wong, Ekin Cheng and Ben Lam) bringing their A-game. Could have used some extra oomph in the finale but I was still super surprised by how much fun I had with this one!
Review by Sam ★★★★ 2 The 4k transfer on Apple TV bumped this a 1/2 star higher. Heh.
Review by Gozu ★★★★ Ich gebe es ja zu. Ich habe eine Schwäche für harte und dreckige HK Action. Der hier ist sogar so dreckig, dass man meinen könnte, die haben das Band vorher nochmal in alten Müllsaft eingelegt. Wong Jing macht hier wirklich keine Gefangenen. Äusserst brutale, blutige Action und auch vor explizit gezeigten Heroinkonsum wird hier nicht Halt gemacht. Das war den Zensoren wohl zuviel des Guten und der Film wurde schlimm zerschnitten. Aber die Österreicher haben es irgendwie geschafft 12 Jahre nach Release die Uncut Fassung aufzutreiben und das ist auch dringend nötig gewesen. Denn "Return To A Better Tomorrow" ist ein mächtiges Heroic Bloodshed Brett. Da gehören blutige Shootouts nunmal einfach dazu. Lässt der Titel noch ein billiges Rip Off…
Review by j__guerrero ★★★ Definitely a cash grab with the title and I wish it wasn’t because it’s a fine action movie all by itself. The cast is pretty good and there’s plenty of melodramatic drama to go around. There’s zero relation to the infamous John Woo series but there’s are some great shoot outs and an enticing story.
Review by Albert F. ★★★½ 1 Great to see this film again. I didn't remember how good it was. It has all Wong Jing ingredients to enjoy together with John Woo's style action choreography. Definitely one of those fast paced films that deserve more attention when talking about the most enjoyable Hong Kong brainless action films.
Review by Austin ★★★★★ Like with The Last Blood before it, Wong Jing injects the heroic bloodshed genre with his distinctive, always entertaining flair. Featuring ridiculous action, a compelling story, and great performances from Ekin Cheng and Lau Ching-Wan. I watched this on iTunes in 4K Dolby Vision and it looked absolutely stunning.
Review by Pascal Grenier ★★★½ Malgré le titre, ce film du prolifique Wong Jing n’a rien à voir avec la série A Better Tomorrow même si on peut y voir de nombreux clins d’œils sans que ce soit pompeux ni du plagiat pour autant. Je dirais même que c’est un des meilleurs films du très inégal réalisateur/producteur de cette période.L’humour pipi-caca est relayé au vestiaire (pour notre plus grand plaisir) et ça ressemble un peu (un blueprint) à ce que va devenir la future série populaire des Young and Damgerous don’t le premier volet est sorti deux ans plus tard.La révélation est Lau Ching-wan qui ira ensuite obtenir ses meilleurs rôles dans les films de Johnnie To. “I’m not a wise guy. But I’m not a fool”.Les fusillades sont beaucoup moins nombreuses mais néanmoins solides y compris une courte séquence entièrement plagiée dans Payback avec Mel Gibson (la scène où il tire avec deux revolvers couché en dessous d’une camionnette).
Review by Chan Chiu-wai ★★★ Wong Jing's Return to A Better Tomorrow (1994) by no means is a perfect cinema. Cheaply ripping of A Better Tomorrow's title doesn’t help either but Ekin Cheng and Lau Ching-wan made up for everything to make it a bearable crime film.
Review by Max S. ★★★★ 2 Beachtet nicht den Namen, der offensichtlich von der sehr erfolgreichen "A Better Tomorrow"-Trilogie abkupfert, denn dieser düstere und stellenweise verdammt harte Heroic Bloodshed-Streifen hat es in sich. Ich konnte es selbst nicht glauben.... vor allem wenn man bedenkt wie viel albernen Mist Wong Jing normalerweise dreht.Hier wollte es aber der Regisseur wissen und das sieht man auch am Cast (u.a. mit Lau Ching-Wan, Ekin Cheng, Michael Wong, Chingmy Yau). Die Handlung ist durchschnittlicher Rachestory-Brei aber die Atmosphäre und die Shootouts nehmen durchaus mit.... ganz zu schweigen vom Gewaltgrad bei dem Wong Jing einfach IMMER eine Schippe drauf legt.Ja. Der Film hat mich positiv überrascht und bei genau diesem Regisseur hätte ich so einen Grad an Ernsthaftigkeit definitiv nicht erwartet. Daumen hoch dafür!
